content: The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" allows magistrate judges to have contempt authority. The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" grants United States magistrate judges the power to exercise contempt authority, including the ability to punish summarily by fine or imprisonment any contempt of their authority that obstructs the administration of justice. The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" grants United States magistrate judges the power to exercise contempt authority in civil consent and misdemeanor cases, allowing them to punish disobedience or resistance to their lawful orders with fines or imprisonment. Contempt proceedings must follow the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" grants magistrate judges the authority to exercise civil contempt powers in misdemeanor cases, allowing them to impose penalties not exceeding those for a class C misdemeanor. Additionally, magistrate judges can order sanctions under various statutes and rules without limitations. The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" empowers magistrate judges to certify facts of contempts to district judges, who then hear evidence on the behavior in question for possible contempt adjudication. The "Magistrate Judge Improvement Act of 2000" allows magistrate judges to certify facts of contempts to district judges, who then hear evidence on the behavior in question and may punish the person in the same manner as for a contempt committed before a district judge. Magistrate judge authority in petty offense cases is amended in Title 18 and Title 28 of the United States Code. Magistrate judges now have the power to enter sentences for petty offenses and class A misdemeanors with consent. SEC. 4 addresses magistrate judge authority in cases involving juveniles. SEC. 4 amends Section 3401(g) of title 18, United States Code, granting magistrate judges the authority to handle petty offense cases involving juveniles and exercise powers under chapter 403.
